author: yorker129-7.bsky.social
text: The problem with the "it should start in the north" angle is HS2 is designed to fix a specific problem of a lack of rail capacity on the West Coast Main Line between London and the Midlands. Starting it in the north would, at best, do nothing for that.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
2 ‚Äì the pessimistic. 

Remember that the ‚Äòwestern leg‚Äô of HS2 includes some things that are definitely being retained under plans for Northern Powerhouse Rail. 

That means everyone could agree that _some_ HS2 safeguarding would be retained.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
June/July 2025 is perhaps the worst time ever to say ‚Äòlet‚Äôs have more HS2‚Äô. If you‚Äôd said ‚Äòlet‚Äôs go‚Äô in mid-June, all the news in July would have people questioning your sanity. 

The optics look better after the summer. Especially from a party conference platform in Liverpool.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
1 ‚Äì the optimistic. The most important fact about HS2 is that it‚Äôs going through a really necessary reset. This is, bluntly, more important than where the line ends up.

The Stewart Review (on which more another time) did not pull its punches.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
HS2 originally had two ‚Äòlegs‚Äô ‚Äì one east to Leeds; one west to Manchester and Liverpool. The eastern leg was cancelled first. And now 550 properties are being returned. 

The western leg is still under discussion.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
Do you remember how I said that government has rules about compulsorily purchased land? If you take it, and you don‚Äôt need it, you have to give it back.

Well, in that last announcement government gave back a lot of _other_ HS2 land.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
July passed. I kept worrying I‚Äôd missed a headline. After all, the plan had been ready to go at the Spending Review. 

The last announcement was the six monthly report to parliament on HS2. 

And I opened it up.

And now it‚Äôs ‚Äúin due course‚Äù

This is getting silly.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
In particular, there were some quirks in the language and promises of the Spending Review that left some suspicious areas of fog, and pointed to a big announcement on ‚Äònorthern rail ambitions‚Äô later that month.

My bet was that this would include the HS2 plan.

author: danielholt.mstdn.games.ap.brid.gy
rbnicholson.bsky.social
text: On BBC Sounds in full now, on podcast apps in two tranches of 5 as part of "Understand", and on air on Radio 4 every weekday from now until next Friday, a new series from Whistledown: "Derailed: The Story of HS2"

author: rbnicholson.bsky.social
text: Featuring the engineers who dreamed it up, the politicians who tried to get it done, and the ordinary people who stood up against it, our new series, "Derailed: The Story of HS2", gets under the skin of the ambition and the fiasco that followed.

author: rbnicholson.bsky.social
text: But we went back to the beginning - and found a far more complex and interesting story than we ever expected. HS2 is not a simple set of failures, or a classic tabloid scandal. It's a story that, as it has unfolded, has exposed deep national dysfunction.

author: rbnicholson.bsky.social
text:
HS2 is - everyone admits - a mess right now.

A big idea with cross-party support, it's become a decade long embarassment. Controvery, scandal and taxpayer cash are leaking out at pace, with no apparent way to stop the flow. 

www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/...

HS2 is cited as ‚Äòthe poster child for value for money issues‚Äô. The project has a run rate of ¬£20m per day so any reviews or resets can become very expensive, very quickly.

author: jpspencer.bsky.social

Megaprojects are defined here as having a total cost over ¬£10bn with strategic benefits, cross-cutting impacts and multi-parliament lifespans. 

Previous examples include the Channel Tunnel, the 2012 Olympics and Crossrail.

author: anthonypainter.bsky.social
text:
In comparison, the Dogger Bank offshore wind energy array is likely to total ¬£10bn for the *same* energy capacity.

That is a quarter of the Sizewell C current estimate (which will be much greater) with miniscule decommissioning costs and waste by comparison. 

(Yes, I know about baseload)

author: anthonypainter.bsky.social
text:
You can make it cheaper. By making it less safe and secure. That's the trade-off. As it has always been. Because...it's not clean power.

Sizewell C is probably necessary, though you can bet it will be nearer ¬£80bn than ¬£40bn. But we should absolutely see this as transition technology, nothing more.
